issues.description: The problem statement (UML and task description) specifies addGuestStudents as addGuestStudents(int, String) — i.e., it should accept an int (number of new guest students) and a String (reason). The solution implementation provides addGuestStudents(int) with only a single int parameter and no place for the reason. This is a signature mismatch: students following the specification will implement a two-parameter method, but the solution/reference uses a different signature. This discrepancy can confuse students about the expected API and will cause mismatches with any tests or reference usage that expect the two-parameter signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem specification by changing the solution method signature to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, String reason) and (optionally) make use of the reason (e.g., log or store it). Alternatively, if the intended design is a single-parameter method, update the problem statement/UML to specify addGuestStudents(int) and remove the reason parameter from the spec. Prefer updating the solution to accept (int, String) to preserve the documented educational intent.

issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) requires a method addGuestStudents(int, String) that accepts a number of new guest students and a reason (String). The solution implementation provides addGuestStudents(int) with only the integer parameter (no String reason). This mismatch in method signature (parameter list) creates a semantic inconsistency: students following the problem spec will implement/expect a two-parameter method, while the solution accepts only one. This can confuse students about the required API and how to map the exercise requirement to the provided implementation.
